overall_building_description: The Canadian Tire Mezzanine Reduction project involves a comprehensive structural modification of the existing mezzanine level, focusing on the installation of new guard posts and guardrails to enhance safety and compliance with the Ontario Building Code (OBC). The project scope, as outlined in the key plan, involves the integration of new C8x11.5 steel channels, which are to be installed to match existing connections, ensuring continuity in load transfer and structural integrity. The guard posts are specified to be installed at a maximum spacing of 48 inches on center, providing lateral stability and preventing excessive deflection under load conditions. The new 42-inch high guardrail system is designed to match existing construction and connections, featuring rails at the top, bottom, and middle, with a 1-inch by 6-inch kick plate installed between posts to prevent debris from falling off the mezzanine edge. The existing mezzanine framing, decking, and sub-floor are to remain unchanged, maintaining the current load-bearing capacity and structural configuration. The project requires the installation of two exit stairs from the mezzanine, as mandated by the OBC due to the area constraints, ensuring safe egress for the occupant load of seven people. The maximum travel distance from any point on the mezzanine to an exit is limited to 45 meters, subject to verification by the architect, to comply with fire safety regulations. The framing plan, not to scale (N.T.S.), provides detailed notes on the structural connections and safety requirements, guiding the construction process. The use of C8x11.5 channels is critical for maintaining the structural performance of the mezzanine, providing adequate support for the guardrail system and ensuring effective load distribution across the mezzanine floor. The project emphasizes the importance of matching existing construction details to maintain aesthetic consistency and structural reliability. The installation process must adhere to precise fabrication requirements, including the use of appropriate welding techniques and bolt specifications to ensure secure connections. The project also involves careful coordination with architectural elements to verify travel distances and ensure compliance with all relevant building codes and standards. The integration of new structural elements with existing systems requires meticulous attention to detail, ensuring that all modifications enhance the overall safety and functionality of the mezzanine level. The project highlights the critical role of structural engineering in adapting existing spaces to meet evolving safety standards and functional requirements, demonstrating the importance of precise engineering design and execution in commercial building projects.
